snippet: Manufacturers have ramped up production of a common air-conditioning coolant, counting on a windfall for destroying a byproduct under a United Nations program.
abstract: Manufacturers mostly in India and China have ramped up production of a common air-conditioning coolant, counting on a windfall for destroying a global warming byproduct under a United Nations program; credits can be sold on international markets, earnings tens of millions of dollars a year; UN and the European Union are trying to undo the unintended bonanza, but the lucrative incentive has become so entrenched that efforts to roll it back are proving tricky, even risky (Series: Chilling Effect).

byline.original: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL and ANDREW W. LEHREN
byline.contributor: Elisabeth Rosenthal reported from Gujarat State, India, and Andrew W. Lehren from New York.

lead_paragraph: Manufacturers have ramped up production of a common air-conditioning coolant, counting on a windfall for destroying a byproduct under a United Nations program.

headline.seo: Incentive to Slow Climate Change Drives Output of Harmful Gases
headline.main: Profits on Carbon Credits Drive Output of a Harmful Gas
headline.print_headline: Carbon Credits Gone Awry Raise Output of Harmful Gas
